chunk_text: [SECTION: COMPANY_DESCRIPTION] Tesla is an electric vehicle, energy systems, and artificial intelligence company. It designs EVs, energy storage, solar products, and autonomy technologies. Its mission is to accelerate the world’s transition to sustainable energy.

[SECTION: BUSINESS_SEGMENTS] Tesla operates three core business segments: - Automotive - Energy Generation & Storage - Services & Other Automotive includes EVs, autonomy software, robotaxi, and insurance. Energy includes Megapack, Powerwall, solar, and VPPs. Services include charging, used vehicles, service centers, and AI compute.

[SECTION: REVENUE_MODEL] Tesla generates revenue from: - Vehicle sales - Full Self-Driving software and subscriptions - Supercharging revenue - Regulatory credits - Used vehicles - Vehicle servicing and insurance - Energy products (Megapack, Powerwall) - Solar installations - Software subscriptions and grid services

[SECTION: RISK_FACTORS] Key risks include: - Declining US EV market share (38%) - Strong competition from legacy automakers - Margin pressure from price reductions - Supply chain constraints (battery materials) - Heavy dependence on Elon Musk’s leadership - Controversial $1 trillion pay package - Regulatory uncertainty around autonomy - EV tax credit expiration and geopolitical risk

[SECTION: ESG] Tesla’s mission is to accelerate the world’s transition to sustainable energy. Environmental sustainability is central to its operations, products, and long-term goals. Tesla customers avoided 32 million metric tons of CO2e in 2024, a 60% increase compared to 2023. Each Tesla vehicle avoids approximately 35 tons of CO2e over its lifetime, and in the US, the average avoided emissions is 52 tons. Tesla is striving for net-zero greenhouse gas emissions across its entire value chain: supply chain, manufacturing, vehicle use, and end-of-life phases. The company aims to first ensure that all operational electricity consumption is matched with renewable energy. Tesla has operated a 100% renewable Supercharger network for four consecutive years, and Gigafactory Berlin has used 100% renewable electricity for two years. Energy products such as Megapack provide grid stability at competitive prices and allow utilities to reduce renewable curtailment. Tesla’s global Virtual Power Plants delivered 2.8 GWh to the grid in 2024, with more than 100,000 Powerwalls enrolled worldwide. The Puerto Rico VPP alone delivered 444 MWh to stabilize the grid during heat waves. Megapack at the Kapolei Energy Storage facility in Hawaii supports 16% of Oahu’s peak load and reduces renewable curtailment by 69% over five years compared to conventional systems. Tesla’s sustainability strategy includes waste reduction, water efficiency, and improved manufacturing processes. The company reached 100% waste diversion away from landfills in certain factories and reduced natural gas consumption by 50% year-over-year. Tesla procured over 1 GW of renewable energy to power its operations. Product safety is a key sustainability pillar. Autopilot safety data shows Tesla vehicles achieve 6.77 million miles per accident with Autopilot engaged compared to the US average of 0.70 million miles per accident. Vehicle fires occur at a rate of 6.5 per billion miles for Tesla vehicles compared to 55 for the national average. Social sustainability priorities include workforce development, safety training, and apprenticeship programs. Tesla’s employee injury rate declined to 2.28 using ASTM standards. The company received over 731,500 employee improvement suggestions related to safety, quality, and operations. Tesla’s supply chain governance enforces strict standards on human rights, materials sourcing, and environmental responsibility. In 2024, Tesla processed 5.3 GWh of battery materials and recovered 590 metric tons of valuable materials through recycling. The company promotes circularity by reintegrating recycled materials into new battery production.

[SECTION: EXTERNAL_SUMMARY] Two major external summaries reflect Tesla’s broader business risks and investor perspective. Summary A — Corporate Governance & Musk Compensation: Tesla’s board proposed a $1 trillion, 10-year pay package for CEO Elon Musk. The package aims to retain Musk, who the board views as critical for Tesla’s future AI, robotics, and robotaxi strategy. The plan gives him 96 million restricted shares worth over $31 billion, with milestones tied to earnings and valuation. Critics warn that this sets a dangerous governance precedent, misallocates investor capital, and concentrates power. Musk threatened to leave if his demands were not met, and the board feared AI talent would follow him. Summary B — EV Market Share Decline & Competition: Tesla’s US market share fell to 38%, its lowest since 2017, as competitors launched new EVs with aggressive incentives. Legacy automakers such as Hyundai, Honda, Toyota, and Volkswagen are gaining share. Tesla faces margin erosion due to price cuts and slowing demand. Analysts note Tesla risks losing ground without new mass-market models.

[SECTION: FINANCIAL_KPIS_2024] Key Tesla 2024 financial performance metrics: - Total revenue: approximately $97.7 billion in 2024. - Net income: approximately $7.13 billion (GAAP). - Gross profit: approximately $17.45 billion. - Gross margin: approximately 17.9%. - Automotive gross margin: approximately 18.4%. - Energy & Storage gross margin: approximately 26.2%. - Year-over-year revenue growth: approximately +0.9%. These metrics reflect Tesla’s 2024 performance and highlight slowing growth but strong profitability in Energy & Storage.
